In the dc limit $\omega\rightarrow0$, the above results reduce to the SMR~\cite{ref:SMRexp1,ref:SMRexp2,ref:SMRtheory}. Moreover, we see from Eq.~\eqref{eq:Z1} and~\eqref{eq:Z2} that $\mathrm{Re}[\Delta Z_2]=\mathrm{Im}[\Delta Z_1]$, but this equality breaks down if the imaginary part of the spin-mixing conductance $G_i$ is included in our calculation. In Fig.~\ref{fig:smi}, we plot $\Delta Z_1(\omega)$ and $\Delta Z_2(\omega)$ as functions of the frequency $\omega$, with all quantities scaled by the longitudinal SMR. Fig.~\ref{fig:smi} shows that the SMI differs from the SMR only in the vicinity of the STT-driven ferromagnetic resonance. 

We notice that the Oersted field generated by the current density $\bm{J}_c$ is also responsible for the SMI~\cite{ref:STFMR}. But one can distinguish the feedback contribution and the Oersted field contribution from the symmetry of SMI with respect to $(\omega-\omega_H)$. For instance, $\mathrm{Re}[\Delta Z_1]$ due to the dynamic feedback is symmetric around $\omega_H$ as shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:smi}, whereas it is antisymmetric when the Oersted field is dominating. In a recent experiment~\cite{ref:SMI}, the observed SMI is negligibly small, and the symmetry pattern around resonance indicates that the Oersted field effect overwhelms the dynamic feedback. This result is probably attributed to the fact that their FM is too thick (55nm) and the NM is too thin (4nm). According to our Eq.~\eqref{eq:Z1}, ~\eqref{eq:Z2} and~\eqref{eq:PQ}, however, when $d_N<\lambda (7.3$nm in YIG~\cite{ref:YIGexp}), the deviation of SMI from the SMR scales roughly as $d_N/d_M$. Therefore, to observe the feedback contribution to the SMI, reducing (increasing) the FM (NM) layer thickness is preferred.
